misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Sort Synchronization (Assuming linked movement)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(studentScores) will reorder studentScores and also automatically reorder studentNames in the same way, keeping each name matched to its original score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(int[]) only sorts the provided int array in place. It has no knowledge of any other array, so it cannot (and will not) move elements in studentNames. Parallel arrays require an explicit coordinated swap (e.g., sorting indices, or sorting pairs/objects) to keep name-score associations intact.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed top student name does not correspond to the highest score after sorting; name/score pairing becomes incorrect.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think when the scores move, their matching names will move in the names array too

String topStudentName = studentNames[highestScoreIndex];
int topStudentScore = studentScores[highestScoreIndex];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort one array (studentScores), the corresponding elements in the parallel array (studentNames) will automatically move along with their paired values to maintain the original pairing relationship.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java's Arrays.sort() operates on a single array in isolation. It sorts only the array it's given and has no knowledge of parallel arrays. When studentScores is sorted, the studentNames array remains completely unchanged. The indices no longer correspond to the same students. The student's mental model assumes arrays are 'linked' or that sorting one array automatically reorders related arrays, but Java has no concept of parallel array relationships.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print the correct highest score, but it will pair it with the wrong student name (the name that happens to be at the last index of the unsorted names array, not the name of the student who actually earned that score). For the given example, it would output 'Charlie (92)' instead of 'Bob (92)'.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are created with the same size and used to store related data (parallel arrays), operations like sorting one array will automatically reorder the elements in the other array to maintain the index-to-index correspondence.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The Arrays.sort() method only has a reference to the specific array passed to it and cannot perceive or modify other arrays in the program. Maintaining the relationship between parallel arrays during a mutation (like sorting) requires the programmer to manually implement a sorting algorithm (like Bubble Sort) that swaps elements in both arrays simultaneously, or to use an Object-Oriented approach.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think when the scores move, their matching names will move in the names array too

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(studentScores) will not only reorder the scores array, but will also automatically move/reorder the corresponding elements in the separate studentNames array so that names and scores stay aligned by index.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. Arrays.sort(studentScores) mutates only the studentScores array; it has no knowledge of (and cannot automatically coordinate with) a separate studentNames array. Therefore, after sorting scores, the index-based correspondence between names[i] and scores[i] is broken unless the program explicitly performs the same swaps/reordering on studentNames (or uses a combined structure like Student objects, or sorts indices).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed top student name can be incorrect even though the top score is correct (e.g., prints "Charlie (92)" instead of "Bob (92)" for the sample input).

evidence.code_snippet: // I think when the scores move, their matching names will move in the names array too

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they call Arrays.sort() on the studentScores array, the corresponding elements in the studentNames array will automatically be rearranged in parallel to maintain the name-score correspondence. They express this explicitly in their comment: 'I think when the scores move, their matching names will move in the names array too'
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student has misunderstood how Java arrays work. In Java, Arrays.sort() operates only on the single array it is called on. Other arrays, even if they are meant to be parallel to the sorted array, remain completely unaffected. When studentScores is sorted from {85, 92, 78} to {78, 85, 92}, studentNames stays as {"Alice", "Bob", "Charlie"}. The indices no longer correspond to matching data. The programmer must manually maintain correspondence by swapping elements in both arrays simultaneously during sorting, or by using a different approach (like creating a custom comparator with a wrapper class or manually swapping pairs). Parallel arrays require explicit synchronization from the programmer; there is no implicit coupling between them.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program prints 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'. After sorting scores in ascending order, index 2 contains the highest score (92), but studentNames[2] is 'Charlie' instead of 'Bob' because the names array was never reordered.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think when the scores move, their matching names will move in the names array too

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when two arrays are used in a parallel fashion (sharing the same indices for related data), Java internally tracks these relationships. Consequently, they believe that invoking a method like Arrays.sort() on one array will automatically trigger the same reordering in the other array to keep the data synchronized.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The Arrays.sort() method only has access to and only modifies the specific array passed as an argument. There is no implicit binding between two separate arrays even if they have the same length or were populated in the same loop. To sort parallel arrays, the programmer must manually implement a sorting algorithm (like Bubble Sort) where every swap in the primary array is mirrored in the secondary array, or use a custom object to encapsulate the data.

evidence.code_snippet: // I think when the scores move, their matching names will move in the names array too
